markdownRemark.html:
Differentiating between Face Verification and Recognition

  • Face verification

    • We input an image and a name ID
    • A face verification method outputs if the image belongs to that claimed name ID
    • Face verification is typically easier than face recognition
    • This is because we only need to verify a single face to one ID
    • Specifically, the accuracy needs to be around 9999%99

  • Face recognition

    • We input an image
    • A face recognition method outputs if the image belongs to any name IDs
    • Face recognition is typically harder than face verification
    • This is because we need to verify a single face to many IDs
    • Specifically, the accuracy needs to be around 99.9999.99%99.99

Motivating One-Shot Learning

  • Typically, we'll only have a single image associated with a name ID in our database
  • Most face recognition systems need to learn from this one image
  • Consequently, the learning algorithm trains on a small sample
  • This problem is called the one-shot learning problem
  • The one-shot learning problem is one of the main challenges for most face recognition systems

Describing One-Shot Learning

  • Instead of learning the weights from a convolutional network, we want to learn a similarity function
  • This similarity function measures the difference between two images
  • Specifically, the similarity function is defined as the following:
d(x1,x2)=∥f(x1)−f(x2)∥22d(x_{1}, x_{2}) = \Vert f(x_{1}) - f(x_{2}) \Vert_{2}^{2}d(x1​,x2​)=∥f(x1​)−f(x2​)∥22​
  • Where x1x_{1}x1​ and x2x_{2}x2​ are two different images

  • Where f(x1)f(x_{1})f(x1​) and f(x2)f(x_{2})f(x2​) are the activations of a fully-connected output layer from a siamese network

    • We will talk about the siamese network in the next section

  • The similarity function returns:

    • A small number if the two images are similar
    • A large number if the two images are different
  • This is defined as the following:
d(img1,img2)≤τ  ⟹  similard(img_{1}, img_{2}) \le \tau \implies \text{similar}d(img1​,img2​)≤τ⟹similar d(img1,img2)>τ  ⟹  differentd(img_{1}, img_{2}) > \tau \implies \text{different}d(img1​,img2​)>τ⟹different
  • Here, τ\tauτ represents some threshold hyperparameter
  • This is the root of all face verification problems
  • For face recognition, we would need to calculate this similarity function on the input image and each image in our database

Introducing Siamese Network

  • A siamese network is a convolutional network found in face recognition problems
  • Roughly, a siamese network encodes an input image into a 128128128-digit vector
  • Specifically, a siamese network architecture refers to running two different images on an identical network
  • A siamese network is trained such that the similarity function ensures encodings (or output layer) of the same person return a small value

  • In other words, a siamese network learns parameters such that:

    • If xix_{i}xi​ and xjx_{j}xj​ are the same person, then ∥f(xi)−f(xj)∥22\Vert f(x_{i}) - f(x_{j}) \Vert_{2}^{2}∥f(xi​)−f(xj​)∥22​ is small
    • If xix_{i}xi​ and xjx_{j}xj​ are different people, then ∥f(xi)−f(xj)∥22\Vert f(x_{i}) - f(x_{j}) \Vert_{2}^{2}∥f(xi​)−f(xj​)∥22​ is large
  • Formally, parameters of a siamese network define an encoding f(xi)f(x_{i})f(xi​)
  • Formally, an input image xix_{i}xi​ will be encoded into a 128128128-digit vector f(xi)f(x_{i})f(xi​)

Defining the Triplet Loss Function

  • A siamese network uses a triplet loss function
  • The triplet loss function is defined as the following:
tp=∥f(xa)−f(xp)∥22−∥f(xa)−f(xn)∥22+αtp = \Vert f(x^{a}) - f(x^{p}) \Vert_{2}^{2} - \Vert f(x^{a}) - f(x^{n}) \Vert_{2}^{2} + \alphatp=∥f(xa)−f(xp)∥22​−∥f(xa)−f(xn)∥22​+α L(xa,xp,xn)=max⁡(tp,0)\mathcal{L}(x^{a}, x^{p}, x^{n}) = \max(tp, 0)L(xa,xp,xn)=max(tp,0)
  • Here, f(xa)f(x^{a})f(xa) refers to the encoded activations of an anchor image
  • Here, f(xp)f(x^{p})f(xp) refers to the encoded activations of a positive image
  • Here, f(xa)f(x^{a})f(xa) refers to the encoded activations of a negative image
  • An anchor image refers to an input image we want to test
  • A positive image refers to a saved image that is the same person from the anchor image
  • A negative image refers to a saved image that is not the same person from the anchor image

Describing the Triplet Loss Function

  • The term triplet loss comes from always needing to train on three images at a time
  • Therefore, we will need multiple pictures of the same person
  • For example, we may need 101010 pictures for each person
  • We want the encodings of the anchor image to be very similar to the positive image and very different from the negative image
  • Formally, we want the following:
∥f(xia)−f(xip)∥22≤∥f(xia)−f(xin)∥22\Vert f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{p}) \Vert_{2}^{2} \quad \le \quad \Vert f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{n}) \Vert_{2}^{2}∥f(xia​)−f(xip​)∥22​≤∥f(xia​)−f(xin​)∥22​
  • This can also be written as the following:
∥f(xia)−f(xip)∥22−∥f(xia)−f(xin)∥22≤0\Vert f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{p}) \Vert_{2}^{2} - \Vert f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{n}) \Vert_{2}^{2} \quad \le \quad 0∥f(xia​)−f(xip​)∥22​−∥f(xia​)−f(xin​)∥22​≤0
  • We can satisfy this equation by setting each term to 000:
∥f(xia)−f(xip)⏟0∥22−∥f(xia)−f(xin)⏟0∥22≤0\Vert \underbrace{f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{p})}_{0} \Vert_{2}^{2} - \Vert \underbrace{f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{n})}_{0} \Vert_{2}^{2} \quad \le \quad 0∥0f(xia​)−f(xip​)​​∥22​−∥0f(xia​)−f(xin​)​​∥22​≤0
  • Obviously, we don't want our network to train our images such that our encodings become equal to 000
  • Meaning, the encoding would be equal to the encoding of every other image
  • Therefore, we need to modify the objective such that our terms are smaller than 000:
∥f(xia)−f(xip)∥22−∥f(xia)−f(xin)∥22≤0−α\Vert f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{p}) \Vert_{2}^{2} - \Vert f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{n}) \Vert_{2}^{2} \quad \le \quad 0 - \alpha∥f(xia​)−f(xip​)∥22​−∥f(xia​)−f(xin​)∥22​≤0−α
  • We need to tune the hyperparameter α\alphaα to find the right threshold
  • The hyperparameter α\alphaα is referred to as a margin
  • Including α\alphaα will prevent our network from learning those trivial solutions
  • We can reformulate the formula to be the following:
∥f(xia)−f(xip)∥22−∥f(xia)−f(xin)∥22+α≤0\Vert f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{p}) \Vert_{2}^{2} - \Vert f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{n}) \Vert_{2}^{2} + \alpha \quad \le \quad 0∥f(xia​)−f(xip​)∥22​−∥f(xia​)−f(xin​)∥22​+α≤0

Example of the Triplet Loss Function

  • Let's say we set α=0.2\alpha=0.2α=0.2
  • Then, our output could be the following:
∥f(xia)−f(xip)∥22+α⏟0.2=0.5\Vert f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{p}) \Vert_{2}^{2} + \underbrace{\alpha}_{0.2} = 0.5∥f(xia​)−f(xip​)∥22​+0.2α​​=0.5 ∥f(xia)−f(xin)∥22=0.51\Vert f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{n}) \Vert_{2}^{2} = 0.51∥f(xia​)−f(xin​)∥22​=0.51 ∥f(xia)−f(xip)∥22+α⏟0.5≤∥f(xia)−f(xin)∥22⏟0.51\underbrace{\Vert f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{p}) \Vert_{2}^{2} + \alpha}_{0.5} \quad \le \quad \underbrace{\Vert f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{n}) \Vert_{2}^{2}}_{0.51}0.5∥f(xia​)−f(xip​)∥22​+α​​≤0.51∥f(xia​)−f(xin​)∥22​​​
  • We can see that these terms satisfy our triplet loss condition
  • Obviously, we would prefer for the gap to be larger between our positive and negative images
  • For example, we'd prefer the following at the very least:
∥f(xia)−f(xip)∥22+α⏟0.5≤∥f(xia)−f(xin)∥22⏟0.7\underbrace{\Vert f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{p}) \Vert_{2}^{2} + \alpha}_{0.5} \quad \le \quad \underbrace{\Vert f(x_{i}^{a}) - f(x_{i}^{n}) \Vert_{2}^{2}}_{0.7}0.5∥f(xia​)−f(xip​)∥22​+α​​≤0.7∥f(xia​)−f(xin​)∥22​​​
  • Alternatively, we could push the d(a,n)d(a,n)d(a,n) up or d(a,p)d(a,p)d(a,p) down
  • However, we'd obviously prefer to satisfy both conditions

Choosing the Triplets xax^{a}xa, xpx^{p}xp, and xnx^{n}xn

  • We don't want to randomly choose xax^{a}xa, xpx^{p}xp, and xnx^{n}xn
  • If we randomly choose these images, then d(xa,xp)+α≤d(xa,xn)d(x^{a}, x^{p}) + \alpha \le d(x^{a}, x^{n})d(xa,xp)+α≤d(xa,xn) is easily satisfied
  • Therefore, we'll want to choose triplets that are hard to train on when construction our training set
  • Meaning, we want to choose xax^{a}xa, xpx^{p}xp, and xnx^{n}xn so that this is initially true early on in training:
d(xa,xp)≈d(xa,xn)d(x^{a}, x^{p}) \approx d(x^{a}, x^{n})d(xa,xp)≈d(xa,xn)

tldr

  • One-shot learning is a training algorithm
  • Specifically, one-shot learning involves training on two images such that the similarity between the two images is minimized
  • This similarity function is defined as the following:
d(x1,x2)=∥f(x1)−f(x2)∥22d(x_{1}, x_{2}) = \Vert f(x_{1}) - f(x_{2}) \Vert_{2}^{2}d(x1​,x2​)=∥f(x1​)−f(x2​)∥22​
  • A siamese network is a convolutional network found in face recognition problems
  • Roughly, a siamese network encodes an input image into a 128128128-digit vector

  • A siamese network learns parameters such that:

    • If xix_{i}xi​ and xjx_{j}xj​ are the same person, then ∥f(xi)−f(xj)∥22\Vert f(x_{i}) - f(x_{j}) \Vert_{2}^{2}∥f(xi​)−f(xj​)∥22​ is small
    • If xix_{i}xi​ and xjx_{j}xj​ are different people, then ∥f(xi)−f(xj)∥22\Vert f(x_{i}) - f(x_{j}) \Vert_{2}^{2}∥f(xi​)−f(xj​)∥22​ is large
  • A siamese network uses a triplet loss function
  • The triplet loss function is defined as the following:
tp=∥f(xa)−f(xp)∥22−∥f(xa)−f(xn)∥22+αtp = \Vert f(x^{a}) - f(x^{p}) \Vert_{2}^{2} - \Vert f(x^{a}) - f(x^{n}) \Vert_{2}^{2} + \alphatp=∥f(xa)−f(xp)∥22​−∥f(xa)−f(xn)∥22​+α L(xa,xp,xn)=max⁡(tp,0)\mathcal{L}(x^{a}, x^{p}, x^{n}) = \max(tp, 0)L(xa,xp,xn)=max(tp,0)
  • The term triplet loss comes from always needing to train on three images at a time
  • Therefore, we will need multiple pictures of the same person
  • We want the encodings of the anchor image to be very similar to the positive image and very different from the negative image
  • We want to choose triplets that are hard to train on when construction our training set

References
